abstract:
The Lake Roosevelt Habitat Improvement Project (LRHIP) was launched in 1990 to enhance migratory rainbow trout populations and improve subsistence and recreational fishing opportunities for the Colville Confederated Tribes. However, an evaluation in 2011 revealed that although significant efforts were made towards habitat rehabilitation and population monitoring, the methods used lacked clear direction and statistical rigor (LeCaire and Peone, 1991).

To address these shortcomings, a new approach to habitat restoration was developed. This method focuses on restoring natural stream function and includes a clearly defined prioritization strategy. To determine priority areas for habitat improvement, an analytical model called Ecosystem Diagnosis and Treatment (EDT) is employed. EDT uses empirical observations of current fish use and habitat conditions as well as an EDT model to evaluate the potential benefits for improving fish performance in different reaches (Lichatowic et al., 1995; Lestelé et al., 1996; Mobrand et al., 1997; Mobrand et al., 1998).

The development of the EDT model requires rating Level II attributes based on empirical data. To obtain this data, continuous surface water temperature is collected at logger locations in all migratory redband rainbow trout spawning tributaries (LeCaire and Peone, 1991). This temperature data is representative of the entire reach it is located within and facilitates spatial analysis of stream temperature patterns among multiple watersheds in the Sanpoil and Upper Columbia River Subbasins.

The use of this method ensures a more focused and effective approach to habitat restoration by employing a clear prioritization strategy, statistical rigor in monitoring, and an analytical model that considers empirical observations, expert knowledge, and other models to determine high-priority areas for improvement. This results in a more targeted and data-driven approach to enhancing the health and sustainability of rainbow trout populations and ultimately improving opportunities for subsistence and recreational fishing for the Colville Confederated Tribes.

description:
The Lake Roosevelt Habitat Improvement Project (LRHIP), established in 1990, aims to enhance the survival of migratory rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss) and eventually boost Tribal subsistence and recreational harvest in streams on the Colville Confederated Tribes (CCT) reservation (LeCaire and Peone, 1991). The primary objective is to restore thriving and harvestable salmonid populations through rehabilitating stream habitat and restoring ecological function within riparian corridors.

The project faced criticisms during a 2011 evaluation as part of the Northwest Power and Conservation Committees Categorical Review process. The approach to both habitat restoration and monitoring lacked clarity and structure. To address these issues, a new methodology was adopted focusing on natural stream function restoration and a well-defined prioritization strategy.

The Ecosystem Diagnosis and Treatment (EDT) model is used to evaluate priority areas for habitat restoration and protection. This analytical framework combines empirical observations of habitat conditions, fish use from monitoring efforts, expert knowledge, and data from other models and analyses to identify reaches and habitat attributes that are most likely to benefit fish performance (Lichatowic et al., 1995; Lestelé et al., 1996; Mobrand et al., 1997, 1998).

The development of the EDT model involves rating Level II attributes for current conditions. Empirical data-backed Level II attribute ratings are given the highest confidence. The ongoing work under this protocol will provide reach-specific temperature data to rate EDT Level II attributes related to stream temperature. These data will also enable analysis of spatial patterns and variance in stream temperature across multiple watersheds within the Sanpoil and Upper Columbia River Subbasins.

The temperature data (approximately 1m²) collected at logger locations accurately represent the water temperature within the entire reach they are situated. Continuous surface water temperature is collected in all migratory redband rainbow trout spawning tributaries.
